--- "Herrick, Chuck" <chuck.herrick@...> wrote:
> 1. why does it have to be uniform?
> In other words, how do you know that what you need is what I need?

I think that comparing a test result to a test result which is
known to be right, and stored in a seperate file is a good, basic
operation for testing infrastructure.  I think that the 
assertEquals(File,String) interface is simple enough so that everyone
could benefit from it, and if people wanted more, it would form
a good basis for extension.

> 2. why should this uniformity effort be a responsibility of JUnit?
> In other words, should this be something tossed into a JUnit
> extender?

I do think this is a basic requirement, and should be part of JUnit,
but if you want to toss it in a JUnit extender, that is fine with me.
I don't care that much.  I can see two major reasons for this being
basic testing infrastructure:
1. It makes it much easier for non-programmers to review testcases,
to ensure that what you think are right answers really are right 
answers.  This is especially true for long messages.  If they are
stored as seperate files, just tell the support person, translater,
or copyeditor, to read them and check for mistakes.  If the right
answers are embeded in java code, it is much harder for these people.
2. It makes it much easier to update test cases to react to updates
in software.  This is a huge problem.  For example, lets say you have
2000 test cases all of which have your company's name.  Your company
changes names.  If they are stored in seperate files, almost anyone
can quickly edit the change.  Maybe even automatically.  If they are
in Java files, it is much harder, because you need to see the context
before you make the change.  (Some of the old company's names might
still be right.)

The whole point of JUnit is to encourage people to build and run
test cases.  Lots of test cases.  If we then make it hard to update
them as things change, people will write fewer test cases.  And things
always change.

> 3. why not use the Unix paradigm and build big tools from little
> tools?
> As an example, what happens if you wrap the ">" command in a script,
> or in a separate Java framework which you build to manage your
> "mature development process"?

I've tried systems much like this, and have found them very dangerous!
The problem is that it is easy for wrong results to be saved as 
correct ones.  Once you have made this mistake, it is very hard to
detect it.  (All the automation which makes it easy to run tests, and
quickly see the results, now work against you in realizing that the
'right' answers are really wrong.)

In a sense, Text files are as basic a computer object as Strings or
numbers.  By storing right answers all alone in their own files, I 
think it makes it easier to use UNIX's various utilities on them.
Right now, it is very hard, because the right answers are interspersed
with the Java code of the test cases.

Joshua Levy
